deliberation: I checked for imagery beyond the basic statement that the righteous die. The only clearly figurative expression is the idiom שָׂם עַל־לֵב, ‘to put upon the heart,’ for ‘to pay attention / consider.’ Other elements (perishing, being gathered) can be read straightforwardly.

instances.english_text: and no one puts [it] upon [his] heart
target: people’s reflective response to the death of the righteous
vehicle: placing an object upon the heart
posture: prophetic critique of their lack of concern
instances.explanation: The idiom ‘to put upon the heart’ figuratively portrays attentive consideration as if something were physically placed on the heart, the seat of thought and feeling.

deliberation: I looked for imagery around ‘peace,’ ‘rest,’ and ‘walking.’ The verse uses (1) death of the righteous as peaceful rest on a couch/bed, and (2) ‘walking straight’ as a path metaphor for upright conduct.

instances.english_text: He shall come to peace; they shall rest on their beds
target: the state of the righteous after death
vehicle: coming to peace and resting on a bed
ground: tranquility, freedom from turmoil and suffering
posture: reassuring portrayal of the righteous’ fate
instances.explanation: The verse depicts the death of the righteous as ‘coming to peace’ and ‘resting on beds,’ a metaphor likening death to entering a peaceful rest after toil.

instances.english_text: one who walked straightforward
instances.explanation: ‘Walking straightforward’ is a standard path metaphor in Hebrew, picturing righteous conduct as walking on a straight road without deviation.

deliberation: I examined the familial labels. The audience is not literally born of a sorceress, adulterer, or prostitute; these are evaluative metaphors describing their character and religious infidelity.

instances.english_text: you children of a sorceress
target: the addressed people and their spiritual identity
vehicle: offspring of a practitioner of occult arts
ground: participation in forbidden magical/religious practices, inherited pattern of rebellion
moral likeness to an impure parent
posture: sharp prophetic denunciation of their religious practices
instances.explanation: Calling them ‘children of a sorceress’ metaphorically characterizes the people as morally and religiously descended from sorcery, emphasizing their complicity in occult practices.

instances.english_text: offspring of an adulterer and a whore
vehicle: offspring (seed) of an adulterer and a prostitute
ground: moral degradation associated with adultery and prostitution
posture: accusation of spiritual adultery and moral corruption
instances.explanation: Describing them as ‘offspring of an adulterer and a whore’ metaphorically equates their spiritual and ethical infidelity with gross sexual unfaithfulness.

deliberation: The gestures (opening the mouth, sticking out the tongue) can be literal signs of mockery. The clearly figurative elements are the genealogical labels ‘children of iniquity’ and ‘seed of falsehood,’ personifying sin and falsehood as parents.

instances.english_text: Surely you are children of iniquity
ground: being generated and shaped by wrongdoing, thoroughly characterized by it
posture: strong denunciation, framing them as essentially produced by sin
instances.explanation: ‘Children of iniquity’ metaphorically makes iniquity their parent, personifying wrongdoing and portraying the people as its offspring, wholly formed by it.

instances.english_text: offspring (seed) of falsehood
target: their propensity to deceit and treachery
ground: being produced by and saturated with lying and treachery
instances.explanation: Calling them ‘seed of falsehood’ personifies ‘falsehood’ as a progenitor and metaphorically depicts the people as its offspring, emphasizing that deceit defines their nature.

deliberation: The child sacrifice and locations (wadis, clefts of the rocks) are presented as actual cultic practices. The expression ‘under every green tree’ is a conventional hyperbolic-idiomatic formula in prophetic texts for widespread idolatrous worship rather than literally every tree.

instances.english_text: under every verdant tree
target: the extent and ubiquity of their idolatrous practices
vehicle: multiple shady cult-trees scattered in the land
ground: widespread occurrence, many cult sites, habitual practice
instances.explanation: ‘Under every green tree’ is a stock prophetic hyperbole and idiom for pervasive illicit worship at many cult sites, not literally at every single tree.

deliberation: I focused on ‘smooth stones of the wadi’ as ‘your portion/lot.’ ‘Portion’ and ‘lot’ are covenantal terms for one’s deity/inheritance (often YHWH). Here the stones (idol-objects) are said to be their portion, which is a metaphorical inversion of covenant inheritance language.

instances.english_text: Among the smooth [stones] of the wadi is your share; they, they are your lot
target: the people’s chosen deity and ultimate allegiance
vehicle: smooth stones of the wadi as ‘portion’ and ‘lot’
ground: exclusive attachment and identification with an allotted share, treating idols as the true inheritance instead of YHWH
posture: ironic exposure of their idolatry as a perverse ‘inheritance’
instances.explanation: By calling the smooth stones ‘your share’ and ‘your lot,’ the text metaphorically transfers covenant-inheritance language (normally of YHWH) to inanimate idol-stones, showing where their true allegiance lies.

deliberation: I considered whether the ‘couch/bed’ is literal furniture at a high place or symbolic. Given the sexualized language in the surrounding context, the ‘bed’ on a high hill functions metaphorically for cultic/adulterous liaisons (spiritual adultery) at the high places.

instances.english_text: On a high and lofty hill you have set your couch
vehicle: a lover’s bed set on a high hill
ground: intimate, illicit, exposed and shameless union
unfaithfulness and pursuit of forbidden partners
instances.explanation: The ‘couch’ placed on a high hill metaphorically represents Israel’s idolatrous cult on the high places, cast as an adulterous bed where she betrays YHWH.

deliberation: The verse is saturated with sexual imagery (‘you uncovered yourself from me,’ ‘you widened your bed,’ ‘you loved their bed’), used elsewhere in prophets for spiritual adultery. I treat this cluster as a single extended adultery metaphor for idolatry and foreign alliances.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי מֵאִתִּי גִּלִּית וַתַּעֲלִי הִרְחַבְתְּ מִשְׁכָּבֵךְ ... אָהַבְתְּ מִשְׁכָּבָם
instances.english_text: For, abandoning Me, you uncovered yourself and went up; you made your couch wide ... you loved their bed
target: relationship with YHWH vs. other powers
vehicle: an unfaithful woman widening her bed and loving adulterous beds
ground: eager pursuit of multiple forbidden partners, betrayal of exclusive covenant, shameless intimacy with others
posture: depicts their religious/political compromises as shameless adultery against God
instances.explanation: By speaking of uncovering herself, widening the bed, and loving others’ beds, the verse metaphorically casts Israel’s idolatry and alliances as sexual adultery against YHWH.

deliberation: I weighed whether actions toward ‘the king’ are literal diplomacy or figurative. The climactic phrase ‘you abased yourself down to Sheol’ goes beyond political description into hyperbolic downward imagery, portraying extreme self-humiliation as a descent to the realm of the dead.

instances.english_text: and you abased yourself down to Sheol
target: the extent of Israel’s degrading efforts to court foreign power/idols
vehicle: descending in humiliation to Sheol, the realm of the dead
extreme downward movement into the underworld
ground: utter abasement, going to the lowest possible level, self-destructive compromise
posture: condemns their alliances as self-debasing to the point of figurative death
instances.explanation: ‘You abased yourself down to Sheol’ hyperbolically and metaphorically portrays their political-religious self-humiliation as a descent into the realm of the dead.

deliberation: I examined the imagery of ‘many ways’ and weariness. The verse uses a journey metaphor for their policies/pursuits, and the phrase ‘life of your hand’ is idiomatic/metaphorical for the vitality/benefit they obtain, sustaining their efforts.

instances.hebrew_text: בְּרֹב דַּרְכֵּךְ יָגַעַתְּ ... חַיַּת יָדֵךְ מָצָאת
instances.english_text: Though wearied by the abundance of your ways ... you found the life of your hand
target: their manifold political-religious pursuits and the motivation they draw from them
vehicle: many ‘ways’ as long journeys that cause physical weariness; ‘life of your hand’ as revived bodily vigor
ground: exertion in pursuing schemes, yet renewed motivation because they find some benefit/satisfaction
posture: critical depiction of relentless, self-serving striving
instances.explanation: Their ‘ways’ are metaphorical roads of policy or idolatry that tire them like travel, while ‘the life of your hand’ idiomatically portrays renewed vigor/benefit that keeps them from giving up.

deliberation: I again checked for idioms and metaphors. The key figurative expression is the repeated idiom ‘you did not put [it] upon [your] heart’ for failing to reckon with God. Other elements (God’s silence, their fear of others) can be read literally.

instances.english_text: you did not put [it] upon your heart
target: their failure to remember and fear God
vehicle: physical laying of an object on the chest
posture: rebuke for thoughtless disregard of God’s patience
instances.explanation: The idiom pictures truly taking God into account as if setting something on the heart, metaphorically using a physical act for mental-emotional attention.

deliberation: The phrase ‘your righteousness’ (צִדְקָתֵךְ) appears in a context of judgment where these ‘righteous acts’ are condemned as useless. This is best read as ironic—the term usually positive is used sarcastically, undercutting their supposed righteousness.

instances.english_text: I will declare your righteousness and your deeds, but they shall not profit you
target: their self-perceived pious deeds and claims of righteousness
vehicle: the word ‘righteousness’ applied to them in a context of exposure and condemnation
praise-terminology used in a derisive way
ground: discrepancy between their claim and God’s evaluation; the supposed ‘righteousness’ is in fact worthless
posture: sarcastic undermining of their pretended righteousness
instances.explanation: Calling their works ‘your righteousness’ while declaring that these will not help them is an ironic use of the term, exposing their ‘righteousness’ as illusory.

deliberation: I looked at the fate of their ‘gatherings’ and the contrast with those who trust in God. The phrase ‘a wind shall lift them up, a breath shall carry them away’ metaphorically depicts the utter transience and powerlessness of their supports (idols/allies).

instances.english_text: and all of them a wind shall lift up, a breath shall carry away
target: their ‘gatherings’ or collections (of idols/supporters) and their hoped-for help
vehicle: chaff-like objects borne off effortlessly by wind/breath
light debris scattered by air currents
ground: frailty, ephemerality, and inability to withstand trial
posture: disparaging their supports as weightless and transient
instances.explanation: The supports they rely on are pictured as insubstantial things that a mere wind or breath can carry away, highlighting their total helplessness compared to those who trust in YHWH.

deliberation: I considered whether the road-building is literal or figurative. In Isaiah’s usage (‘prepare the way’), the commands to build up the road and remove obstacles form a metaphor for preparing access to salvation/God, where ‘stumbling blocks’ represent spiritual or practical hindrances.

instances.hebrew_text: סֹלּוּ־סֹלּוּ פַּנּוּ־דָרֶךְ הָרִימוּ מִכְשׁוֹל מִדֶּרֶךְ עַמִּי
instances.english_text: Build up, build up a highway! Clear a road! Remove every obstacle from the road of My people!
target: the process of restoring God’s people to relationship and to their land
vehicle: constructing and clearing a road, removing physical obstacles
ground: eliminating hindrances, creating free access, making movement easy and direct
posture: encouragement and command to remove barriers to restoration
instances.explanation: The commands to build and clear a highway metaphorically describe removing spiritual and practical hindrances so that God’s people can freely advance into His promised restoration.

deliberation: I noted two main figurative patterns: (1) God’s exaltation portrayed by spatial height (‘high and lifted up,’ dwelling in the height), and (2) the ‘reviving’ of the broken spirit/heart, which uses life imagery for spiritual restoration and treats ‘spirit/heart’ as the inner person.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי כֹה אָמַר רָם וְנִשָּׂא ... מָרוֹם וְקָדוֹשׁ אֶשְׁכּוֹן
instances.english_text: For thus says the One who is high and lifted up ... ‘In the high and holy place I dwell’
vehicle: being high and lifted up, dwelling in the height
ground: supremacy, separation from ordinary creatures, majesty
posture: assertion of God’s exalted nature as the backdrop for His mercy
instances.explanation: God’s transcendence is portrayed through vertical-spatial imagery—being ‘high and lifted up,’ dwelling in the ‘height’—a metaphor for supreme exaltation and holiness.

instances.hebrew_text: לְהַחֲיוֹת רוּחַ שְׁפָלִים וּלְהַחֲיוֹת לֵב נִדְכָּאִים
instances.english_text: to revive the spirit of the lowly and to revive the heart of the crushed
target: the inner condition of humbled, broken people
vehicle: reviving a spirit/heart that has lost life
bringing something dead/near death back to life
ground: restoring vitality, hope, and strength where there was collapse and despair
posture: gracious assurance of deep inward restoration
instances.explanation: ‘Revive the spirit/heart’ metaphorically portrays God’s work as giving life again to the inner person whose courage and hope have been crushed.

deliberation: I looked for metaphors and idioms. The main figurative feature is the use of ‘spirit’ and ‘souls’ (נשׁמות) to denote human beings collectively; that is a metonymy. The rest (God’s contention and anger) can be read in straightforward covenantal-legal terms.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי־רוּחַ מִלְּפָנַי יַעֲטוֹף וּנְשָׁמוֹת אֲנִי עָשִׂיתִי
instances.english_text: for a spirit would grow faint before Me, and souls are what I have made
target: human beings who are subject to God’s judgment
vehicle: spirit and souls as the inner-breath/life of persons
ground: the life given by God that can be exhausted by His wrath
dependence and fragility of human life
posture: stressing God’s compassion based on human frailty
instances.explanation: ‘Spirit’ and ‘souls’ stand metonymically for the human beings God has made, whose inner life would be crushed by unending wrath.

deliberation: The key figurative element is ‘he went backsliding in the way of his heart’—the ‘way of the heart’ is a path metaphor for following one’s inner inclinations rather than God’s way.

instances.english_text: and he went, backsliding, in the way of his heart
vehicle: walking along a ‘way’ that belongs to the heart
taking a path determined by inner impulses
ground: persistent pursuit of one’s own desires, turning from God’s path
posture: depicts their stubbornness as choosing their own road over God’s
instances.explanation: The ‘way of his heart’ is a metaphor where inner desires (‘heart’) map onto a roadway that the sinner travels, highlighting self-directed backsliding.

deliberation: Two main figures appear: (1) ‘his ways’ (דרכיו) as the now-familiar path metaphor for conduct, and (2) ‘I will heal him’ using sickness/healing imagery for spiritual-moral restoration and forgiveness.

instances.english_text: I have seen his ways
target: the person/people’s patterns of life and conduct
ground: a habitual course taken repeatedly, directionality, and destination
posture: acknowledgment of their actual behavior, as a basis for mercy
instances.explanation: ‘Ways’ metaphorically denotes their conduct, likening their moral choices to roads along which they travel.

instances.english_text: and I will heal him
target: their damaged spiritual/moral condition and broken relationship with God
vehicle: healing an ill or wounded body
ground: removal of dysfunction, restoration to wholeness and well-being
posture: tender promise of restorative grace after judgment
instances.explanation: God’s forgiveness and restoration are portrayed as ‘healing,’ mapping spiritual-moral brokenness onto bodily sickness that the divine Physician cures.

deliberation: I noted three distinct figures: (1) ‘fruit/produce of the lips’ (ניב שפתים) for spoken words, (2) ‘peace, peace to the far and to the near’ as a merism for all whom God restores, and (3) ‘I will heal him’ continuing the healing metaphor for spiritual restoration.

instances.english_text: creating the fruit (produce) of the lips
target: the words of peace/healing that God causes to be spoken
vehicle: fruit/produce growing from lips as from a plant
ground: that speech issues forth from a source and can be abundant, beneficial output
posture: depicts God as author of restorative speech and praise
instances.explanation: ‘Fruit of the lips’ metaphorically describes spoken words (especially praise and peace-proclamations) as produce that lips ‘grow,’ emphasizing God’s role in generating them.

instances.english_text: Peace, peace to the far and to the near
target: all those whom God restores, regardless of distance/status
vehicle: the pair ‘far’ and ‘near’ spanning extremes of distance
ground: total inclusiveness across the spectrum, from one extreme to the other
posture: emphasizes the wide reach of God’s peace
instances.explanation: ‘To the far and to the near’ functions as a merism, using spatial extremes to signify all whom God calls into His peace, whether distant or close.

instances.english_text: and I will heal him
target: the spiritual-moral wounds of those far and near
ground: repairing damage, restoring wholeness and functionality
posture: affirms concrete restorative action accompanying the proclamation of peace
instances.explanation: As in v.18, ‘I will heal him’ uses bodily healing as a metaphor for God’s restorative work on the spiritually and communally broken.

deliberation: The verse contains an explicit simile—‘the wicked are like the troubled sea’—and then personifies the sea (it cannot rest; its waters drive out mire and mud), extending the image of restless wickedness.

instances.english_text: But the wicked are like the troubled sea that cannot rest
target: the inner and outward condition of the wicked
vehicle: a storm-tossed sea driven and churned
ground: constant agitation, lack of rest, inability to be calm
posture: sharp characterization of wickedness as inherently chaotic
instances.explanation: The wicked are explicitly likened to a driven, stormy sea—this simile captures their inner unrest and unstable behavior.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי הַשְׁקֵט לֹא יוּכַל וַיִּגְרְשׁוּ מֵימָיו רֶפֶשׁ וָטִיט
instances.english_text: for it cannot be still, and its waters toss up mire and mud
target: again, the nature and effects of wickedness
ongoing activity and consequences of the wicked
vehicle: a sea that ‘cannot rest’ and whose waters ‘drive out’ muck
sea acting with will and force
ground: inability to cease harmful activity and the continual production of moral filth and harm
posture: vividly condemns the unceasing and polluting activity of the wicked
instances.explanation: The sea is personified as an agent that cannot rest and that actively hurls out dirt, mirroring how the wicked inexorably churn out moral and social pollution.

deliberation: ‘There is no peace for the wicked’ is a proverbial, but essentially straightforward, theological statement. Though ‘peace’ (שָׁלוֹם) is rich in meaning, the sentence itself does not employ a distinct metaphor, simile, or other figure beyond standard abstract language.
